urn:contentItem:5PP9-1GP1-F15W-H2PC-00000-00PAUL KRUGMAN, PROFESSOR OF ECOMONICS AND NOBEL PRIZE-WINNING ECONOMIST, UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING THE ECONOMY AND POLITICS2017-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:22ZLexisNexisPAUL KRUGMAN, PROFESSOR OF ECOMONICS AND NOBEL PRIZE-WINNING ECONOMIST, UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING THE ECONOMY AND POLITICS

October 10, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

PAUL KRUGMAN, PROFESSOR OF ECOMONICS AND NOBEL PRIZE-WINNING ECONOMIST, UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK,

CHATTERLEY: What'd You Miss? President Donald Trump is looking for unity on tax reform. Earlier today he said that he would be making some changes to the framework that was originally unveiled last month. The announcement comes as key senators raise concerns with the specifics of the plan which includes eliminating the state and local tax deduction.

Let's bring in Paul Krugman. He's Nobel Prize-winning economist, columnist of the New York Times and a professor at the City University of New York.

Professor Krugman, it's an honor to have you on the show. Thank you so much.

KRUGMAN: Great to be on.

CHATTERLEY: Prospects for tax reform for this administration?

KRUGMAN: Well, you know, I can never - I'm not a legislative expert. I mean, intellectually it's completely incoherent. They seem to have fallen - they seem to have lost the thread on what it is they're trying to do. They have no way to actually accomplish, you know, anything that looks remotely like deficit neutrality without actually sharply raising taxes on a lot of middle class people. So, it's a mess. Now, that wouldn't be the first time that something that was a mess made it through Congress. But, it's not looking very good.

WEISENTHAL: When you say that it's completely incoherent, what do you mean by that? When you look at the range of policies, what stands out to you as not making any sense?

KRUGMAN: Well, first of all, you know, they keep on saying Americans are overtaxed - the highest taxed country - that's a lie. We're not. Actually, we're just about the lowest taxed among major countries. But, still they keep on implying that they're going to do a tax cut for middle income people. They keep on saying, well, we're not going to - you know, we're responsible fiscally. And, yet, there's no way you can have what they really, really want, which is a huge tax cut for businesses - this pass-through thing which would be a huge tax cut for people with high incomes without somehow or other raising taxes on a lot of people to pay for it. So, they haven't figured out a way to make the thing hang together at all.

FU: And, don't forget the middle class tax cut that they've been promising as well.

KRUGMAN: Well, there is no middle class tax cut in there. In fact, there's a substantial middle class - you know, random pieces of the middle class tax increase in everything we've seen so far. So, yeah - they - I mean, they had a couple of ways they thought they were going to be able to pay for it, one of which involved, you know, repealing the Affordable Care Act

FU: That didn't go so well.

KRUGMAN: The other of which involved the border tax adjustment. Since both of those have died, now they have absolutely no idea how to make the arithmetic work.

CHATTERLEY: You just pushed back on the idea that the United States is one of the highest taxed. You said actually it's one of the lowest.

KRUGMAN: Yes. If you just take taxes as a share of GDP

CHATTERLEY: Right.

KRUGMAN: Then among advanced countries, we're right at the bottom. Now, you know, there were - you can try to make some excuses. We have a relatively high top-line corporate tax rate

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

KRUGMAN: But on the other hand we have lots and lots of deductions and so on. So, our effective corporate tax rate is only sort of normal and our individual taxes are definitely low. So, it's amazing that Trump just repeats this again and again. And, it's as flatly false as anything there is in the world.

WEISENTHAL: On the corporate tax side, leaving aside the individual taxes for the moment - on the corporate tax side, are there ways that you think that taxes could be reformed in a productive way that would make things more efficient - more logical?

KRUGMAN: Well, it's actually kind of funny. The reform that Paul Ryan originally floated early this year - the destination-based cash flow tax which included the border tax adjustment, was a not stupid idea. In fact, it was one of the few things I've seen from Paul Ryan

WEISENTHAL: This is a big moment where Paul Krugman is praising something that Paul Ryan

CHATTERLEY: Not stupid.

KRUGMAN: No. It's actually - in fact it has kind of bipartisan support among tax experts. People like Alan Auerbach were saying this is a good idea. I support - so, and of course, it being the one thing that I've seen from Paul Ryan that was really not a terrible idea, it died instantly in the political arena. And, without that - without the border tax adjustment that's a piece of that, there's no way to make a significant corporate - you know, cut in corporate marginal tax rates that doesn't explode the deficit.

CHATTERLEY: I'll ask you about Art Laffer and the Laffer Curve and the implications for Kansas and what happened there.

KRUGMAN: Yes.

CHATTERLEY: Is that a specific example of where something didn't go wrong because they made mistakes or does that theory just be - has been blown out of the water by the example?

KRUGMAN: Oh, it's been blown out of the water by every single example we've seen, right? There has been not a single case where anything like the Laffer Curve has seemed to be true. I mean, there was Kansas - I mean a state level is actually an especially favorable case for it because capital labor can easily flow into a state. So, the chances that cutting taxes might actually increase revenue is much higher

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

KRUGMAN: At the level of one state than it is for the United States as a whole. And, even so, all it did in Kansas was create a fiscal crisis. And, nothing - look, the Clinton tax hike was supposed to destroy the economy. Then we had the best boom of the post-war era. Obama substantially increased taxes in 2013. Nothing terrible happened. So, this is a - there is nothing supporting this point of view except the fact that some very rich people would like it to be true.

CHATTERLEY: So, based on all that, wouldn't (ph) we understand the impact of tax cuts in aggregate, is that a fair argument to make - a fair point to make?

KRUGMAN: Well, there is very little reason to think that tax cuts matter much one way or the other for underlying growth. I mean, the (base) would have to cut taxes is you cut tax collection. That's basically what happens.

CHATTERLEY: If you're arguing this case, that actually a lot of the financing is going to be provided by higher growth as a result of the tax cuts

KRUGMAN: You might as well just assume that unicorns will come and deliver packages of money, right? There's no reason to believe this.

CHATTERLEY: OK.

FU: I need to ask you about healthcare, because the President says that he plans to sign executive action to allow new health plans outside of Obamacare, creating more healthcare options for people. That's his sell. Now, experts say this would destabilize already fragile markets. So, what happens in the interim? Because, whatever plan he does open this up to wouldn't take affect right away.

KRUGMAN: Yes. The thing however is you have - you know insurers have to make decisions about whether to participate in the market. They have to submit requests for premiums. So all of this - all of this is uncertainty is wreaking huge damage already. So, you know, premiums are going way up for 2018 and most of that - most of that is because of the Trump administration and the uncertainty it's created.

FU: So can it survive until 2019?

KRUGMAN: Well, yes, because most people - even in the individual market, most people are receiving subsidies which cushion them from the increases. And, then there's Medicaid, which is unaffected by all of this. So, it gets worse but it doesn't collapse.

FU: Right. Nobel Prize-winning economist Professor Paul Krugman is sticking with us for the next hour.

Coming up next we're going to talk about the President's search for the next fed chair and whether the central banks' independence is perhaps at risk.

This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

FU: What'd You Miss? Concern that the search for the next fed chair may take a political turn - Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Krugman wrote in his column last week "surely it's possible, even probable that the Federal Reserve, like other government agencies, is about the get Trumpified, that one of American policies last remaining havens of competence and expertise will soon share in the general degradation."

Professor Krugman is back with us and not holding back on opinion here. What is an example of a Trumpified fed pick versus one that showcases the fed's competence and expertise?

KRUGMAN: Well, there's a very clear dichotomy here, right? We have a perfectly fine fed chair who could be reappointed. Janet Yellen has probably every indicator - done a stellar job. Why not just keep her? On the other hand we - for a while there, the betting (ph) was kind of - the prediction markets were thinking that the most likely pick was Kevin Warsh, former fed governor who has - there's a lot of things you can say about them (ph) - but, one thing is he does have a track record over the past decade and it's quite consistent. He's been wrong about everything.

FU: Economic forecast

KRUGMAN: Economic forecast, worried about inflation as the world was sliding into depression, worried that terrible things - thought that fiscal policy was going to be - you know, we were going to turn into Greece. It's amazing. It's kind of almost awesome. You can almost make money by taking whatever he thinks is going to happen and betting the other way - but, politically correct from a republican point of view - has some family connections with Trump. So, that would have been - you know, he might still be appointed, although apparently his stock has declined a little bit.

WEISENTHAL: How much do you weigh concern of a - what you would see as a bad pick, and obviously it sounds like you don't think Kevin Warsh would be a good pick

KRUGMAN: Right.

WEISENTHAL: A bad pick versus a pick who is perceived to be at Trump's beck and call - and so, Trump calling him out - him or her out on Twitter for a rate hike - stuff like that. Which of those would concern you more?

KRUGMAN: Well, boy, both. I mean, in some ways - I think those go together. I don't think they really separate, because you had somebody who was actually good and respected within the fed and respects the institution of the fed - that person is also not going to be particularly pressurable by the White House. So, it's a - if you had somebody who had no real reason for being there except the fact that Trump decided that he liked him or her, although it's going to be a him, if that's who it is - then that would then be the kind of person you would worry about being politicized.

CHATTERLEY: We've seen U-turns on many occasions in Donald Trump. Do you think there's a chance here that his criticism of Janet Yellen was made perhaps before he'd spoken to people who may have known more about monetary policy and actually having learned subsequently - he's perhaps realizing that continuity of the fed might not be a bad thing and actually reappoint Janet Yellen at the end?

KRUGMAN: Well, I'm hoping so. I mean, that would be the best outcome I think given what's happening right now.

CHATTERLEY: But, you don't think

KRUGMAN: You know, his U-turns tend to be followed by further U- turns. Every time you think he's reached a reasonable agreement on something, then he finds a way to go back on it. So, I worry about that, even here.

CHATTERLEY: Even there.

WEISENTHAL: Speaking of Janet Yellen, and speaking - getting away from the question of who the next fed chair is going to be, one of the most notable things going on in the economy is the persistent failure of the fed or the economy overall to get to 2 percent inflation - to hit the inflation goal (ph). In light of what we've seen over the last several years - all of the things that have tried - have you changed or evolved in your thinking of what the fed can do to hit inflation? What have you learned about the fed and inflation by watching this persistent short-fall?

KRUGMAN: OK. There's two different things. One is monetary policy just doesn't have that much traction when interest rates are very low. That still remains true. Even though the fed has normalized a little bit, we're still kind of in that regime

WEISENTHAL: Right.

KRUGMAN: Where the fed - all of the attention is on the fed and yet the fed has much less power than it would in what we used to think of as normal times.

The other thing is, there is something going on in the inflation process. It looks as if - you know, whether it's the natural rate of unemployment, if such a thing exists, is weighed down, or the Phillips Curve has gotten flatter or there's downward nominal wage rigidity or something. But, something - clearly the underlying models we were using to try to predict inflation, which were never very good, are now looking completely useless (ph).

WEISENTHAL: Do you have a favorite theory or explanation for what that something is?

KRUGMAN: I think it's a mix - there still being pent-up wage cuts that don't want to happen and there's just sort of - there's still an overhang from the past. And, I think there's nervousness. I think that people having been through the Great Recession and the long, slow recovery are just very reluctant to grant or demand wage increases that might end up being locked in during the next slump.

FU: So, does that mean that the Federal Reserve should re-think its approach to targeting 2 percent inflation? Should it give up that target?

KRUGMAN: Oh, no, on the contrary. I mean, everything we've seen that says that 2 percent inflation is if anything, too low, that given that we've seen how hard it is to get inflation up once it's too low, given that it's - I'm a secularist stagnation guy - that we really need to have the opportunity of having significantly negative real interest rates, that the fed's target should be above 2 percent

FU: What - 3 percent?

KRUGMAN: Well, I would - I mean, I would - I'm old enough. I'm older than all you guys. I remember a 4 percent. I remember Reagan's second term when we had 4 percent inflation. It wasn't so bad. It gave you a lot more room for monetary policy. So, I would go there. It's not - it's a long way from being politically acceptable but, no - by no means to say that because we're having trouble getting to the 2 percent target which actually looks too low, that we should give up on even trying to get there.

WEISENTHAL: Could the fed be not hiking right now? If you were a fed chair, would you not be

KRUGMAN: I would not be hiking right now. I think the fed is trying to normalize and that version of normality went out the window ten years ago.

FU: Economist Paul Krugman is sticking with us, because we're talking about changing political dynamics in the age of Trump. We can take that in many directions.

From New York, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

FU: What'd You Miss? Republican Senator Bob Corker is in open opposition to the President, calling the White House "an adult daycare center," and worrying whether President Trump can lead the nation to a Third World War - or, whether he would. But, perhaps the real battle is within the Republican Party itself.

We're back with Paul Krugman, Nobel Prize-winning economist.

WEISENTHAL: Paul, one of the interesting things about Corker's comments is he said, "There are a lot of people within my caucus who feel the same way I do." But of course, none of them have really called out Trump to the same degree. What do you think the reluctance is all about?

KRUGMAN: It's about their political careers. I mean, you know, I've been paying attention to this stuff for a long time and I read a lot. Today's republican legislators - people in the senate and even more so in the house, they grew up in an era of a monolithic, very tightly organized Republican Party.

These are not people who courageously staked out a position that might have been unpopular. These are people who joined the political machine that guaranteed them a good living, even if they lost an election, right? We call it "wingnut welfare," all of that, right? And, so they are not - these are apparatchiks. These are not people who are going to step out and take a stand on principle. It's not the kind of people they are. It would require a lot of - Corker turns out to be a more interesting guy than we thought. But, it's also he's decided that his political career is over. There are going to be very few who are willing to do that, even under the most extreme circumstances.

CHATTERLEY: But, you've got now Senator John McCain of course as well, who is getting treatment for brain cancer and you've got Bob Corker - so you've got two kind of

KRUGMAN: So, people who are on the edge of retirement or possibly don't have very long to live are willing to say something that I don't think is going to be enough to be an effectively large caucus.

CHATTERLEY: But, in terms of trying to get legislation through, losing two big senators like that actually, is critical for the GOP.

KRUGMAN: Well, that's right. And, remember, we already - we already saw Obamacare repeal crash and burn

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

KRUGMAN: Tax reform or tax reform tax or whatever it is they're trying to do on taxes is in big trouble. So, it's quite possible that they'll have a completely sterile legislative agenda - and - which, you know, from my point of view is a good thing. In any case, yes. They don't have the kind of margin that would allow them to push stuff through if they have even a few people who decide, oh, the hell with it, I'm just going to say what I think.

FU: Well, the party is in a little bit of a dilemma here, because they've rallied around principles that seem to be in opposition to themselves. For instance, they want tax cuts on investment income to boost the economy. They want tax cuts for the middle class, all the while avoiding widening the budget deficit. You can't have one without the other.

KRUGMAN: Right.

FU: Something's got to give and no one is willing to concede any of that.

KRUGMAN: Yes. We have a phrase that's in other circumstances but it works in international economics - we talk about the impossible trinity. There are three different things that everybody wants and you can only have two of them. And, they've definitely got themselves in the impossible trinity.

They also have the problem which is that Trump sold himself to his base as a populist - I'm going to help you against the swamp and against the big guys and then everything that they're trying to do legislatively is standard republican - you know, let's give more to the oligarchy.

WEISENTHAL: How do you think the tension is going to resolve ultimately? Because, it does seem like there's - you know, the McConnell wing and the Trump wing are distinct, especially in how they see the economy and populism - taxes perhaps. Ultimately do you think the old McConnell wing will just completely be swept out?

KRUGMAN: Oh, no. If you actually look at concrete legislative measures - look at what Trump has actually proposed or at least signed on to - first on healthcare and now on taxes, it's totally been McConnell Ryan wing. There's been no hint at all of that economic populism in anything he actually does. He talks a populist game but in fact his populism never translates into economics.

WEISENTHAL: Right.

KRUGMAN: He's populist on, you know, race relations. He's populist on culture war. But, on economics, there's been no - it appears to be entirely just rhetoric.

CHATTERLEY: So far he hasn't gotten anything done. So, if he actually tries to get legislation passed - I mean he called Chuck Schumer apparently on Friday to try and get something done on healthcare. The risk is that perhaps he tries to see what he can get away with on tax cuts, if not tax reform. Does the sort of bipartisan outreach become the end-game here if he wants to get things done, because he's a deal-maker? He wants action - results.

KRUGMAN: Well, the thing about him as a deal-maker is he tends to re-neg on all of his deals, right? They thought they had a deal on the dreamers. He now suddenly

FU: Now they're outraged.

KRUGMAN: He said, "I'm willing to deal on healthcare." But, you know, now he seems to be imposing other conditions. So, you know, who's going to make a deal with him now, really?

FU: So, what should the democrats do during this time where they may possibly be working with the President on some kind of deal even though they're not confident it's going to come to fruition - because they themselves are at risk of fracturing or splintering into an extreme left and a shrinking moderate presence (ph)?

KRUGMAN: I think that's much exaggerated. If you look on policy substance, there's really not a whole lot of division. You know, we talk about different wings of the Democratic Party but in fact the whole party is pretty much unified in anything that involves policy in the medium term.

FU: Well, right now they're unified against Donald Trump.

KRUGMAN: And, they're also unified for, you know, we're going to defend Obamacare - maybe we'd like single-payer eventually, but even if you look at the standard single-payer plan, most of it is a transition to a public option. So, I think it's much less real division there. I think what the democrats probably do is they, you know, sound flexible, they talk with Trump - they make it clear, we need to talk with Trump, but they don't actually offer him anything much because, why? They know that they'll get shafted if they do and they know that the base will be angry if they do.

CHATTERLEY: Sounds like the debt raise (ph), actually, doesn't it? They actually didn't give up anything and Trump did (ph).

Paul Krugman, Nobel Prize-winning economist joins us for the market close. Stay with us. From New York, this is Bloomberg.

1556

(BREAK)

1559

CHATTERLEY: What'd You Miss? Stocks climb to a record high, as the dollar weakens.

I'm Julia CHATTERLEY.

FU: I'm Scarlet Fu.

WEISENTHAL: And, I'm Joe Weisenthal.

If you're tuning in live on Twitter, we want to welcome you to our closing bell coverage every weekday from 4 to 5 pm Eastern.

FU: Let's begin with Market Minutes. Look, it's another day of record highs here for the Dow and the S&P and the NASDAQ. You could see gains of anywhere from one-tenth of 1 percent to three-tenths of 1 percent. So, the big tech names are probably lagging behind, given the NASDAQ's smaller gain than the other two.

KRUGMAN: Yes, but new highs once again. It's pretty remarkable. The melt-up

FU: The melt-up continues.

All right. Let's look at some individual names here - Proctor & Gamble declaring victory in its bid to keep Nelson Pelts off its board, even as Nelson Pelts' activist hedge fund try-in (ph) said the vote is still too close to call. So, that stock is down just by half of 1 percent.

Wal-Mart gaining almost 5 percent. That's a big move for Wal-Mart after announcing a $20 billion stock buy-back. Also, it says it expects U.S. e-commerce sales to surge 40 percent in the next fiscal year.

And, a quick mention here of UAL and American Air. United Continental surging after bolstering of financial outlook despite hurricanes and a continued fare war and of course as expert (ph) analysts raise their earnings forecast you can see American Airlines getting a little bit of a lift from that as well.

WEISENTHAL: Finally, let's go to the government bond market - very quiet today - hardly anything going on. Tier (ph) yields unchanged. Ten-year yields down moderately. Remember bond yields was closed yesterday for Columbus Day, so this is catch-up - really nothing going on here.

CHATTERLEY: And, that (inaudible) in what we saw in the FX markets as well. I'm showing you a seven-day here for the dollar index. That's actually not a pretty chart, but the dollar is lower for a third day versus most of the G10 tiers (ph). I mean, we talked about those concerns about tax reform. I think we just have to take it as a pause, and the recent rallying looking like its run out of steam.

I'm showing you what's going on in Euro dollar too. Of course, we have that Catalonian presidential talk or speech today to Parliament, stepping back from the prospect of unilateral declaration of independence - he wants to engage. We have got the Euro there above 118, the figure. I also want to show you what's going on in that Euro dollar - sorry, in sterling as well. The rally now that we've seen this week to around 1 percent manufacturing and construction outcome beating (inaudible). The data is showing a pretty mixed picture I'd say for the U.S. economy here, but still more chatter about the Bank of England raising rates in November with a one and done move.

FU: And, just a quick update here on stocks, the Dow finished at a record but the S&P and NASDAQ fell just short.

WEISENTHAL: Finally, on commodities, let's look at oil and gold - oil gaining nearly 3 percent, rising optimism that more countries are going to join with OPEC to cut production. So, some hope (ph) diminished supply up - back up about $50 a barrel in West Texas intermediate to run 51. And, gold futures, gaining again up to just over 12.90 an ounce.

And, those are today's Market Minutes.

CHATTERLEY: Well, you may see a post-election market rally that wasn't predicted. We're still here with Paul Krugman, Nobel Prize- winning economist.

Paul, you made the call that markets would tank if President Trump were elected.

KRUGMAN: Right. And, I retracted it very soon afterwards. And, you know, I did what you should never ever do, which is to let your political, you know, biases, interfere with your judgment. I thought, this is a terrible thing, which it was, but it isn't necessarily going to be terrible for every indicator. And, so, this is a mea culpa. I did that already.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, you did.

KRUGMAN: This was me doing exactly what I tell people not to do. And, you know, it's going to happen. We're all mortal. One thing is worth saying, by the way. We talk about there's a Trump bump. There's also a Merkel bump, a Macron bump, a (inaudible) bump, an (inaudible) bump - stock markets have been up all around the world. So, something's going on. People like stocks.

What is the - I always quote my old teacher, Paul Samuelson (ph), who said that the stock market had predicted nine of the last five recessions. The market may not be telling us much of anything at all, except that for some reason people are liking stocks.

CHATTERLEY: We have a viewer question actually, and I think you've kind of already answered it there, asking whether the Trump stock bump reflects a fundamental change to the economy or just the expectation that business owners will eat a larger piece of the pie with employees and the public at large eating less pie and more externalities like dirty air and water?

KRUGMAN: Yes, or it might just reflect the fact that investors think that other investors are going to pay more for stocks. I mean, it doesn't have to mean anything much at all.

Let me say, just I am little surprised that the market doesn't worry more about the downside of a totally catastrophic response if something bad happens, you know? What if we have something really bad happen and they handle everything the way they handled Puerto Rico? That ought to be some kind of weight on the market. But, we know that markets tend not to - tend to ignore those things until they actually do happen.

FU: You know, I wanted to play for you a comment from Richard Thaler, the Nobel Prize-winning economist ...

KRUGMAN: Yes.

FU: On what he thinks about what's going on the stock market. Take a listen.

WEISENTHAL: Here he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RICHARD THALER, NOBEL PRIZE WINNING ECONOMIST: I don't know about you, but I'm nervous and it seems like when investors are nervous, they're prone to being spooked and nothing seems to spook the market. As you said, it just crawls up, slowly but surely. And, if it's all based on the expectation of some big tax cut, surely investors should have lost confidence that that was going to happen, given what's happened so far out of Congress.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FU: Especially what we've heard of late, Joe, which is the President is going to back to tweak the tax proposal.

WEISENTHAL: Right. So, there's all this uncertainty as you said, like we've seen an example of disaster response and

KRUGMAN: Yes.

WEISENTHAL: Hasn't been impressive. There is active saber rattling about North Korea now almost every other day - threat of our military conflict. So, is your theory that basically markets are not really good forward discounters - basically just take into account what already happened?

KRUGMAN: Yes. We - it's not - that isn't even a theory. That's an observation. We know. And, some of us again remember - you know, remember the housing bubble. And, it was - that was the clearest thing I'd ever seen in my life. That was just overwhelming in numbers. And, yet, month after month the prices kept on rising and people kept saying, oh, there's no - if there were really a bubble, surely it would have burst by now. And, then one day it did.

FU: Do you see a bubble right now?

KRUGMAN: It's much less clear. Let's put it - there were - profits are high. Interest rates are still very low so it makes kind of sense for stock prices to be high, given that. It's more - in this case I don't see it's a really overwhelming bubble. I just think that there's a disaster risk that the markets are not taking into account.

CHATTERLEY: When we ask people about this though they say, look, for the first time in two decades, maybe more, we've got this synchronous growth pattern when they look around the world and actually that lifts all boats. Do you buy that?

KRUGMAN: Well, not necessarily, because sometimes a synchronous growth pattern means that interests rates rise which tends to - and, that's not happening. So, I don't - you know, at some level - look, Bob Schiller famously - he did a study during the '87 stock crash and he asked people, why are you selling - in real time, using fax machines, because that's all you had at the time, and the only answer that appeared with any frequency - you know, there were all kinds of (inaudible) for rationalizations (ph) - the only answer was, I'm selling because stocks - because prices are falling. I think people are buying stocks because prices are rising. And, I think that's all that's really gone

WEISENTHAL: Well, we have a show, so we have to have better (inaudible) than that. If only people just gave us those (inaudible).

CHATTERLEY: We need to (inaudible).

FU: Now, in terms of the economy, I wanted to get your sense of the labor market, because you can't really read too much in the latest jobs report. Yet, people were saying, oh, look at the participation rate, it's gone up. Look at earnings. It's gone up. What do you take away from the latest couple of reports and what it says about the economy?

KRUGMAN: Yes. I'm having a hard time figuring out what the - lately I've been looking at actually at the QUIPS rate, which is back up to normal levels. And, that seems to be signaling that we really are kind of - people seem to feel that it's OK to leave a job because they can find another one, which suggests that we are kind of at full employment. Earnings are not really showing that. Wage increases are still sub-par. But, you know, maybe - and, also it's interesting that prime age labor reports participation is creeping back up to previous levels. So, all the people who said, this is structural, it really is nothing - turns out, no, it's just lack of jobs. So, there's some actual good stuff. And, I wouldn't take one month's number on the NFP very much.

WEISENTHAL: And, just a reminder. We're going to get the QUIPS rate tomorrow - the JOLTS number comes out tomorrow, so something to watch.

FU: Perfect timing.

All right. Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Krugman will be sticking with us. We're going to talk about urban policy and perhaps how to avoid disasters like Hurricane Harvey in Houston - or at least it could have been minimized.

From New York, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

FU: What'd You Miss? We are back now with Nobel Prize-winning economist, Paul Krugman. And, we turn our focus to urban policy and infrastructure.

Professor, you've written about the flooding disaster that was caused by Hurricane Harvey in Houston and how it was largely due to bad policy, including unregulated development.

KRUGMAN: Yes.

FU: Some estimates have the storm causing up to $200 billion dollars in damage.

KRUGMAN: Yes.

FU: So, what's the lesson here? What should be done differently?

KRUGMAN: Well, in Houston it's pretty clear. People have been warning about this for a long time, that it essentially - too much of it is paved. You need to have places to drain. You need to have - you know, you have to - you cannot just - in (ph) what is very much a place that nature wants to flood occasionally - even the side (ph) climate change that wants to happen, even more so now - if you have completely unregulated development then you end up with no place for water to go.

Now the funny this is - the thing that makes it agonizing is, on the other hand, in some ways Houston does it right by not restricting development in ways that prevent people from building housing. So, you know, you have a kind of extreme San Francisco-style which is nimbyism gone wild

FU: Yes.

KRUGMAN: Which is disastrous. And, Houston is a - has much, much cheaper housing because it didn't do that.

On the other hand, you have complete, you know, ignoring the environmental consequences of unrestricted development and we seem to find it very hard politically to find the balance there.

WEISENTHAL: Right. You know, if you look at all the other boom cities over the last decade, New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco - completely unaffordable for homeowners for the middle class - Houston has been a success story on this front - you know, a thriving city economically where middle class people can afford to buy a home.

KRUGMAN: That's right. No. If you look at - I mean, when they (ph) ask why does Texas grow faster in general than the rest of the country, it's none of the things that the Texans like to boast about. It's not because of low taxes. It's not because they're cruel to the poor. It's because they have a housing policy that lets you build houses which the northeast, and even worse, the far west, do not have. But - so, that's a good thing. But, you know, you have to have some place for the water to go when there's a hurricane and they haven't done that.

So, it's a real - it - no one seems to - I mean, the only city that seems to have adequate regulation - big city, and affordable housing, is Chicago. Unfortunately they've also got Chicago winters, so I don't know what you do about that.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, but can you steal (ph) from them in terms of the way they've tackled this, because as you say, I mean, it's kind of bad city planning - the zoning laws - and, we've talked about them on this show before in Houston, also a huge problem. But, then you compare it to San Francisco as well and say actually, look at the situation that they've created, where people have extreme commuting, which actually I've never even heard about.

KRUGMAN: No. Well, we have - you know, we have some of that here. I know people - a couple of people who live in Bucks County and commute to Manhattan.

CHATTERLEY: How long does that take?

KRUGMAN: About two hours.

CHATTERLEY: Wow. (Inaudible) four hours and

KRUGMAN: Yes. No. It's - the thing is, technically there are no problems. We know how to do this. We know what should be done. It's easy to throw up a list. The question is, how

CHATTERLEY: Politics.

KRUGMAN: Politics. And, I don't know if we've found a way to make that happen. It just seems to be - you know, de Blasio came in with very good ideas about trying to expand affordable housing and he's done what in absolute terms is quite a lot in New York. But, of course it's such a huge city that it's just a drop in the bucket relative to the size of the problem.

FU: How much are we going to rely on local politicians, city mayors, state governors to do a lot of the work here, because everything is so gummed up at the federal level?

KRUGMAN: Well, first of all, this is going to have to be local policy in any case.

FU: Sure.

KRUGMAN: Sure, it is going to require local politicians. The trouble - I mean, when people talk about decentralization, the fact of the matter is, by and large, with many - with honorable exceptions, but a lot of local politicians are really pretty terrible. Not that many people vote in state and local elections and so you'll often - you have machine politicians.

CHATTERLEY: You're not getting the best people

KRUGMAN: On the whole, even - you know, much as I can denounce stuff that goes on in Congress, I'm not sure that there are many state legislatures (ph) that I would prefer.

WEISENTHAL: Is there something here in New York City when you look at regulations of the housing marking that you think could be done that a mayor or city council could do to ease housing crisis?

KRUGMAN: Well, sure. I mean, even though we're an enormously enormous city and very dense, there's still lots of potential building. There's lots of places where we could still build up. There's still in fact land that is un-built that could be built without destroying the quality of life. There is - you know, if you're going to have a city - a metro area with 20 plus billion (ph) people, you're going to have to have some really dense developments. And, look, I live - I actually checked - my zip code has got about 70,000 per square mile. It doesn't feel impossibly overcrowded. You know, it's high rises. You can live that way and we need more of that.

CHATTERLEY: Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Krugman is staying with us.

Up next we get his take on the political uncertainty in Europe. From New York, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

CHATTERLEY: Catalonia backs away from declaring independence outright. The Catalan president opted for a middle ground in his message to Parliament today, calling for talks with Spain. But, what will the recent fiscal uncertainty mean for Europe's economy? Paul Krugman is still with us.

Paul, let's talk about Spain to start off with. What do you think here?

KRUGMAN: Well, not at all familiar. I mean, I don't know Spain. I certainly don't know Catalonia. I mean, it's odd to have this timing. I mean, if you were thinking bad things were going to happen in Spain, you would have expected those three or four years ago when the Spanish economy was really in the dumps.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

KRUGMAN: Spain is actually making a comeback and a fair bit of that actually in Catalonia. But, you know, having the auto industry is coming back - Spain is - it's an enormous, incredibly expensive (ph) process of internal devaluation (ph). But, they have finally been - you know, there's some light at the end of the tunnel. So, it's kind of odd to have this happening now.

Now, I understand Catalonia has in fact been deeply oppressed culturally, but you try to think about what it would mean to break Catalonia away from the rest of Spain now. And, my God, it's like trying to imagine Virginia seceding again now, right? It would be a really impossible thing to happen.

CHATTERLEY: But, when you look at Europe optically (ph), I mean we've got - we've had the Macron victory over in France, Angela Merkel has just come back in in Germany - yes (ph) we've got these hot spots like Italy and we've got the tensions now in Spain, but overall what's your sense of Europe at this moment?

KRUGMAN: Well, Europe - the Euro continues to function badly, right? The Euro was a mistake. It has been a big constraint. They paid a huge price in high unemployment but the political cohesiveness of Europe, with the exception of Britain, has turned out to be much stronger. I mean, us Anglo-Saxons didn't quite understand just how deep the commitment of much of the European elite was to it.

WEISENTHAL: In 10 years will all of the countries that are in the Euro zone still be there?

KRUGMAN: You know, if Greece wasn't going to leave the Euro with the 27 percent unemployment and a depression-level slump, who's going to leave? I think it's very, very hard. People just

WEISENTHAL: Right.

KRUGMAN: Don't want to do that, even when the economics of it makes a lot of sense.

CHATTERLEY: They always said in Brussels, "don't underestimate Angela Merkel's will to keep this thing together."

FU: No, that's a really, really good point. Yet, there is an attraction to populism, right? People in Spain, people in France can't turn away from it completely. People in Germany with AfDs

KRUGMAN: That's right.

FU: Strong showing.

KRUGMAN: There are - everybody's got their little Trumps. Everybody's got their - and, not necessarily in countries you would think. You know, Germany - by the way, this is a demonstration that is not - economic anxiety is a very distinctly secondary thing. Germany has been the great success story this whole period. Even so, they have a resurgent hard right.

FU: All right. Well, we want to bring in some viewer questions to wrap it all up - to wrap up your hour with us.

Joe, why don't you start with this one on the broken Phillips Curve?

WEISENTHAL: Yes, so a question about the Phillips Curve - we talked about it a little bit very earlier on. What do you make of it? Some wondering if it's the changing nature of the economy from a manufacturing to a service economy - maybe it was never valid in the first place. What's your take on that debate?

KRUGMAN: Yes. My take is that I don't really know. We're trying - look, some things we can see. We can still see that there's an awful lot - if you look at the distribution of wage changes, there's a spike at zero, which tells us that one thing that's still going on is that people - there are still people who are - really should from a market sense be taking wage cuts and because they can't, there's kind of a pent up demand for wage decline that's sitting there.

Some of it is it may be that expectations - that after years and years of inflation falling below forecasts that that is starting to get reflected in expectations. But, I have to say, all of this stuff - I have a feeling that I'm like a pre-Copernican astronomer, you know, doing epicycles trying to make this model that really doesn't want to - so, the answer is, at some level, we don't know.

CHATTERLEY: Hector (ph) is asking if it's related to the transition mechanism, though - I guess in some sense, did it fall out in the wash at some point?

KRUGMAN: I don't think that there's a - I mean, I don't think that the service economy change or any of the - in general, structural change is overrated, right? Things like - the fact of the matter - that people obviously think it's easy to find jobs, should be showing up in higher wage demands. And, why it isn't showing up is still a puzzle.

CHATTERLEY: A mystery.

FU: Janet Yellen has said so as much.

All right. Final question to you: will the fed be successful in reducing its balance sheet?

KRUGMAN: Oh, yes. I don't - that is really not - the idea (ph) that there was ever going to be a big problem there was always a fundamental misunderstanding. They have plenty of tools to offset it. If they tried to dump it all at once it would be a big problem, but I don't see any problem there.

WEISENTHAL: One last question. We just have a few seconds left. Years ago you said that big coin was even and it hasn't died yet. I'm curious whether you - what you think about it these days, because so many conversations come back to that.

KRUGMAN: Yes, I think it's still evil. I don't think that there is any very legitimate purpose for it. And, yes, it is kind of - it's suspended. I still think it's a Wiley Coyote thing, right?

WEISENTHAL: (Inaudible).

KRUGMAN: You run off the edge of the cliff. One day you look down and realize there's nothing under you. But, I've been saying that for years and it's been wrong all along.

FU: In the meantime, the legs are moving really, really, really fast.

KRUGMAN: That's right.

FU: Paul Krugman, thank you so much.

KRUGMAN: Thanks a lot.

FU: Thank you for spending the time with us.

Nobel Prize-winning economist - he's a columnist for the New York Times and of course, a professor at the City University of New York.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5XFR-4661-F0JC-M28M-00000-00Paul Manister: Why WhatsApp is playing a dangerous security game2019-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:21ZLexisNexisPaul Manister: Why WhatsApp is playing a dangerous security game

At a time when people are worried about how their personal communications are being read, listened to and analysed, WhatsApp has positioned itself as the last bastion of privacy.

Facebook's sister company recently announced it is suing the Israeli cybersecurity company NSO Group for malware attacks on its users, scoring an instant PR coup that earned them headlines in the UK and US.

"At WhatsApp, we believe people have a fundamental right to privacy and that no one else should have access to your private conversations, not even us," said Will Cathcart, WhatsApp CEO, accusing NSO of targeting 1,400 users.

The case is being seen as a turning point in Silicon Valley's fight against private sector firms they claim have used malware to infect customer phones and give them access to messages.

READ MORE: Edinburgh mum warns parents over Momo 'suicide game'

Although NSO has been damaged by claims its technology has been used by rogue governments to target human rights activists, journalists and politicians, they're part of a regulated and flourishing multi-million pound intercept industry that sells this kind of tech to law enforcement and intelligence agencies across the world.

But before anyone feels sorry for WhatsApp, let's consider the double standards at play. Last month WhatsApp published a statement saying it had filed a complaint in the US federal courts against NSO, drawing heavily on genuine public concerns about privacy.

"Mobile phones provide us with great utility, but turned against us they can reveal our locations and our private messages and record sensitive conversations we have with others...governments and companies need to do more to protect vulnerable groups and individuals from these attacks."

But the same accusation could easily be levelled at WhatsApp. Last year, inspired by an interview given by the former director of GCHQ, Robert Hannigan, on the BBC's Today programme, I examined WhatsApp terms and conditions to see exactly what happens when we click to accept. Mr Hannigan's view is that Facebook's primary goal is to squeeze every drop of profit from its users' data.

"This isn't a kind of fluffy charity providing free services," he said, "It's a very hardheaded international business and these big tech companies are essentially the world's biggest global advertisers, that's where they make their billions."

I would go further: if we're talking about technology that can be turned against us, then frankly WhatsApp is the world leader in information exploitation and bulk data collection. Most people, of course, don't read the terms and conditions.

Why would we when WhatsApp's extend to 29 pages of legalese? The first condition we, as users, agree to is that "WhatsApp works and shares information with other Facebook companies."

This means our details are shared with dozens of other companies, all in the field of data user collection.

Another reads: "You provide us ...t he phone number of WhatsApp users and other contacts in your mobile address book on a regular basis."

In other words, this is the entirety of your business and social network, your intellectual property and that of your employers and/or employees.

This is the reason companies, corporations and governments need to be wary when permitting the use of platforms like WhatsApp - it's all too easy to simply click away company data.

WhatsApp's privacy policy covers "the collection, use, processing and sharing of...information to the United States and other countries globally where we have or use facilities, service providers, affiliated companies and partners ... you grant WhatsApp a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty free ... licence to use, reproduce, distribute, create derivative works of, display and perform the information (including your content) you upload, submit, store, send or receive...".

In the US, the lawsuits against Facebook over data privacy issues are piling up, which might explain why it's working so hard to shift the debate in its favour. One, Zellmer vs Facebook, is a class action that highlights the case of Clayton Zellmer who, despite never registering for a Facebook account, says the firm has still built a facial biometric profile for him based on photos uploaded by other users.

According to the legal papers, Facebook has used advanced facial recognition technology to create and store detailed face templates from more than 1 billion users, potentially putting us at risk from identify theft if these identifiers fall into the wrong hands.

READ MORE: Pochettino plays down team unrest after WhatsApp dinner invite

All of this hardly makes WhatsApp the protector of privacy and security. But there is another reason Facebook is keen to flex its muscles by taking on NSO. Founder Mark Zuckerberg wants to establish end-to-end encryption across all three of its apps, including Messenger and Instagram, a move which the US and the UK governments warn will allow paedophiles, terrorists and other serious criminals to conceal their activities.

The US National Center for Missing and Exploited Children have estimated that 70 per cent of the illegal content and activity would be lost with encryption. The simple fact is that all those in Silicon Valley have engineered us to agree, on a mass scale, to the bulk collection of our data. When playing the privacy card to galvanise support, Will Cathcart might start a little closer to home.

- Paul Manister is a communications security consultant.

urn:contentItem:5S54-7VM1-JBCN-435R-00000-00Paul Ryan: Big Tech regulation needed; future lawmakers must rein in Medicare, Medicaid2018-04-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPaul Ryan: Big Tech regulation needed; future lawmakers must rein in Medicare, MedicaidMARK SOMMERHAUSER msommerhauser@madison.com

Outgoing U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan on Friday said he sees an expanded federal role for regulating big technology companies, but that Congress must proceed cautiously in doing so.

Ryan, R-Janesville, also touted new GOP laws to rewrite the tax code and boost military funding. But he said work remains, likely after he leaves office, to rein in health care programs for retirees and the poor.

Ryan's remarks came at a Wisconsin Manufacturers & Commerce event in Madison. They were his first in public in his home state since he revealed last week that he won't seek re-election after two decades in Congress.

A U.S. Senate committee last week held a hearing to grill Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about data privacy for users, among other topics. Asked what the role of federal government is in online data privacy, Ryan said "there's clearly a role," without naming specific companies.

"People's privacy rights are clearly being compromised — what do we do about it?" Ryan said. "We want to make sure that we get it right without stifling innovation."

Ryan also said he isn't sure what he'll do after he leaves Congress and doesn't know if he'll endorse a candidate to succeed him.

Ryan did not take questions from reporters but fielded inquiries for about 45 minutes from a friendly crowd. He painted a rosy picture as his party heads into what's expected to be a tough fight to retain control of the U.S. House in the fall midterms.

"We see a military that's being rebuilt, an economy that's growing," Ryan said.

Democratic Party of Wisconsin spokeswoman Melanie Conklin said Ryan doesn't understand how dissatisfied voters are.

"Speaker Paul Ryan still fails to understand that the work he sees as his legacy — gifting enormous tax cuts to the wealthiest 1 percent and giant corporations at the expense of working people and fighting to take health care away from millions of Americans — is precisely why his Republican Party is so unpopular right now," Conklin said.

For the remainder of 2018, Ryan said he anticipates Congress tackling a rewrite of the Dodd-Frank financial law; the Senate passed a bill last month to ease regulations primarily for smaller banks. Also on tap, Ryan said, are infrastructure measures and a 2018 Farm Bill that would dramatically expand work requirements for food stamp recipients.

He also called for a bipartisan commission to address health care programs for the retired or poor, such as Medicare and Medicaid. Ryan said spending growth in those programs is by far the main concern in balancing future federal budgets.

Asked why, with total control of the federal government, Republicans have not done more to scale back spending or reduce the federal debt or deficits, Ryan said the Republican-controlled House has done its job to pass bills to scale back entitlement programs, but the Senate has not.

"Remember that?" Ryan said, mimicking U.S. Sen. John McCain's "thumbs-down" gesture to vote against the Obamacare repeal bill that was narrowly defeated in the Senate last year. "That one move took the biggest opportunity we've ever had on fundamental entitlement reform and killed it by one vote."

Ryan's announcement about his future came months after enactment of one of his careerlong ambitions, overhauling the federal tax code, which passed in December. But his 2½-year tenure as speaker otherwise was marked by frustrations, legislative and political — and most recently, his uneasy relationship with President Donald Trump.

Ryan's announcement set off scrambles to replace him as House Speaker — and for who will succeed him representing Wisconsin's 1st Congressional District.

Among the Republican candidates who have registered with the Federal Election Commission are Nick Polce, a Lake Geneva businessman and U.S. Army veteran, and Paul Nehlen, an alt-right social media provocateur who was banned from Twitter for making posts viewed as racist and anti-Semitic, and whom Ryan's campaign criticized for "bigoted rhetoric."

Bryan Steil, a Janesville attorney and University of Wisconsin System Regent, is considering a GOP bid and is scheduled to make an announcement Sunday about his plans.

Randy Bryce, a Caledonia ironworker and political activist, and Janesville teacher Cathy Myers are the Democratic candidates. State Rep. Peter Barca, D-Kenosha, the former state Assembly minority leader, also has said he's considering a run.

Applications engineer Kevin Adam Steen, a Republican, announced his candidacy on Thursday. Jeremy Ryan, a liberal known as a prominent protester in Madison who ran as a Republican against Ryan in 2014 but got only 6 percent of the vote, also registered with the state to run again as a Republican. Christopher Guerrero, of Waukesha, is also registered with the state to run as a Democrat.

urn:contentItem:5X1C-G2M1-JC8S-D3RH-00000-00Paxton leading AGs in probe of Google2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:22ZLexisNexisA SECTIONPg. A001Paxton leading AGs in probe of GoogleTaylor GoldensteinAustin Bureau

1) Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton speaks about the antitrust probe outside the Supreme Court. PHOTO: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press 2) Texas' Ken Paxton, left of center, and other states' attorneys general arrive for a news conference in Washington, D.C. Paxton is leading the AGs in a probe of Google and its digital ad practices. PHOTO: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton will lead 50 attorneys general from across the country in an antitrust investigation of Google and its digital advertising practices in another sign of the mounting scrutiny of large tech companies by government officials. The investigation will look into whether the company, which "dominates all aspects of advertising on the internet and searching on the internet," has acted in ways that restricted competition or consumer access, Paxton said at a news conference outside the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday. All states but California and Alabama are involved, as well as the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. "There is nothing wrong with a business becoming the biggest game in town if it does so through free market competition," Paxton said in a statement, "but we have seen evidence that Google's business practices may have undermined consumer choice, stifled innovation, violated users' privacy and put Google in control of the flow and dissemination of online information."

Paxton emphasized that the investigation is not a lawsuit and said investigators have already subpoenaed the company. In a similar move, New York Attorney General Letitia James said Friday that she will lead a bipartisan coalition of attorneys general in an investigation of Facebook. That investigation will examine whether the social media company "endangered consumer data, reduced the quality of consumers' choices or increased the price of advertising," according to a news release . The inquiries come as the Justice Department leads its own antitrust investigation into Google, which the company recently acknowledged. The Federal Trade Commission has been conducting its own competition probe of big tech, as has the House Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust. "Google's services help people, create more choice and support thousands of jobs and small businesses across the United States," Kent Walker, Google's senior vice president of global affairs, said in a statement. "At the same time, it's of course right that governments should have oversight to ensure that all successful companies, including ours, are complying with the law. . We have always worked constructively with regulators, and we will continue to do so." The bipartisan nature of the group is a testament to how such an investigation by state attorneys general is a "no-brainer," if for no other reason than a political one, said James Angel, associate professor of finance at Georgetown University. "It doesn't mean they're actually going to do anything, but given the criticism of Google, it's easy to argue they'd be derelict in their duty if they did not at least investigate," Angel said. "Attorneys general are basically political animals. . They really want to show they're tough, and they're going to go after the bad guys, especially because a lot of them desire to run for governor." The attorneys general also have the advantage of investigating under state antitrust laws that may differ from federal laws and give them more latitude, Angel said. It's too soon to say, Paxton said Monday, what potential remedies could be sought with an investigation such as this. Angel said the range of possibilities is broad - from requiring Google to pay penalties, to forcing it to spin off acquisitions such as online advertising company Double Click, to imposing new regulations that would allow more competitors into the market. Google, far and away the largest online advertiser in the world, will control 31.1 percent of digital ad dollars in 2019, or $103.73 billion, according to market research company eMarketer. Facebook, much further behind in second place, will follow with $67.37 billion. Last year, more than 85 percent of the revenue generated by Google's parent company, Alphabet Inc., came from advertising, according to company filings . "This is not anti-tech," said Utah's Republican attorney general, Sean Reyes, at Monday's news conference. "To the opposite. This is actually for the benefit of the tech ecosystem to help level the playing field." The search giant has been put under a microscope by government entities several times. The company was fined a record $2.72 billion by European regulators in 2017 for abusing its dominance of the online search market. In the U.S., the FTC investigated the possibility of antitrust action against Google but closed the probe in 2013 without taking action. In 2016, Reyes and Washington, D.C.'s Democratic attorney general, Karl Racine, asked the agency to reopen the inquiry, but it declined at the time. Paxton's office said in a news release that none of the previous investigations "fully address the source of Google's sustained market power and the ability to engage in serial and repeated business practices with the intention to protect and maintain that power." The Associated Press contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:5Y0N-Y911-DYTY-C1F4-00000-00PAYBACK TIME2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1,6PAYBACK TIMEDANIEL BINNS

SOCIAL media giants should be forced to hand user data to researchers and pay millions of pounds more in tax to tackle mental health harm caused by their sites, it has been claimed.

The urgent call for action is made in a Royal College of Psychiatrists report backed by the dad of Molly Russell, who killed herself aged 14 after she viewed damaging content on Instagram.

In a foreword, Ian Russell blames 'pushy algorithms' for feeding the schoolgirl a stream of the material and leaving the family to face the 'wrecking ball of suicide'.

He wrote of Molly's social media use: 'Among the usual school friends, pop groups and celebrities followed by 14-year-olds, we found bleak depressive material, graphic self-harm content and suicide-encouraging memes.

'Without research using data from social media companies, we will never know how content can lead children and young people to self-harm or, in the most tragic cases, take their own lives. The government must enact these calls from the royal college.' The report's co-author Dr Bernadka Dubicka warned it revealed mounting evidence of a link between social media use and poor mental health.

She said she had witnessed 'more and more children self-harming and Continued on Page 6 » » Continued from Page 1 attempting suicide' as a direct result of their online activity.

Mr Russell, whose daughter had appeared to be an ordinary 'enthusiastic' teenager before her death in 2017, revealed a note she had left behind.

The TV producer from north London said she wrote: 'I'm the weird sister, quiet daughter, depressed friend, lonely classmate. I'm nothing, I'm worthless, I'm numb, I'm lost, I'm weak, I'm gone. I'm sorry. I'll see you in a little while.

'I love you all so much. Have a happy life. Stay strong xxx.' A two per cent levy on UK revenues of global giants such as Instagram's owner Facebook is to be enforced from April in a bid to ensure payments more fairly reflect what they earn here.

But the RCP is calling for the Digital Services Tax to be applied instead to their international turnover.

Facebook, which earned £1.6billion in the UK in 2018, would have had to fork out an extra £30million that year under the government's plans.

But the RCP proposal would have forced it to pay in excess of £850million from its £42.8billion global revenues.

That is more than the £500million that all the big tech firms combined are expected to pay under the current plans.

The RCP said some of the extra cash should go to fund research and training for professionals working with children.

It also called for universities to be given access to anonymised data on users, such as how much time they spend on sites.

Dr Dubicka said: 'We will never understand the risks and benefits of social media use unless the likes of Twitter, Facebook and Instagram share data.' She added: 'Self-regulation is not working. It is time for government to step up.' Facebook told Metro: 'Making sure people are safe on our platforms is the most important work we do and we are already taking a number of the steps recommended in this report.

'We remove harmful content and provide support for those who search for it. We are working closely with organisations such as the Samaritans, and the government, to develop industry guidelines in this area.' A government spokeswoman said: 'We are developing world-leading plans to make the UK a safer place to be online.

'This includes a duty of care on online companies, overseen by an independent regulator with tough enforcement powers to hold them to account.' Call: 116 123. Find your local branch online at: www.samaritans.org WHAT'S YOUR OPINION? Text the word VIEWS followed by your comment, name and where you live to 65700. Standard network charges apply.

urn:contentItem:60XC-9Y01-F07F-83VH-00000-00Paying for journalism the price of a healthy democracy2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPaying for journalism the price of a healthy democracyDavid Eccles

A government-backed ACCC push to make Google and Facebook pay publishers for Australian news risks backfiring on all parties including consumers, argues Richard Holden. He says that government itself should help subsidise journalism in the interests of dem... A government-backed ACCC push to make Google and Facebook pay publishers for Australian news risks backfiring on all parties...

A government-backed ACCC push to make Google and Facebook pay publishers for Australian news risks backfiring on all parties including consumers, argues Richard Holden. He says that government itself should help subsidise journalism in the interests of dem...

A government-backed ACCC push to make Google and Facebook pay publishers for Australian news risks backfiring on all parties including consumers, argues Richard Holden. He says that government itself should help subsidise journalism in the interests of democracy. Photo: supplied You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian government is considering amending the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 to force Google and Facebook to pay local commercial media organisations for the sharing of their content on the digital platforms. The News Media and Digital Platforms Bargaining Code proposed by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will require the tech and media companies to make terms through “mandatory binding arbitration”. It will also oblige them to divulge parts of their core intellectual property (such Google’s search algorithm). It has been lauded as a world-first in addressing the power imbalance between the platforms and traditional news organisations. Champions such as commission chief Rod Sims argue it’s a simple matter of forcing Google and Facebook to pay a fair price for extracting value from journalism for which they pay nothing. As Sims put it : What this was all about was the imbalance in bargaining power, the market failure that comes from that, and underpayment for news having a detrimental effect on Australian society. Who could argue with that? Even federal treasurer Josh Frydenberg has described it as “a question of fairness”. But from an economic standpoint the whole bargaining code is hopelessly confused. It fails to properly understand the source of competitive pressure for media companies, and why they have lost revenues over the last 15 years. Mandatory binding arbitration between tech and media companies is also a completely inappropriate policy tool to achieve the public policy goal of fostering high-quality journalism. As I have written about in detail for the Stigler Center at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, making the code law risks doing serious harm to Australian consumers while shovelling money to large media companies like Nine Entertainment and News Corp Australia. Faced with the prospect of having to divulge key intellectual property, it would not be surprising if Google and Facebook simply prefer not to be in the Australian market. Millions of Australians using Google, YouTube and Facebook will lose out. Between 2002 and 2018, consulting firm AlphaBeta estimates total annual revenue for Australian newspapers fell from A$4.4 billion to A$3.0 billion. Almost all of this was due to lost classified advertising revenue, worth A$1.5 billion in 2002 but just A$200 million in 2018. “That’s Google’s fault,” you might cry. Actually no. The vast bulk of lost classified advertising revenue was due to online “pure-plays” such as Seek, Domain and Carsales. Google and Facebook took basically none of this revenue. The media companies were sitting on a gold mine of classified advertising. Then there was massive technological disruption due to the internet and smart phones. That, as they say in the classics, is show business. It doesn’t justify making companies who happened to succeed in an adjacent space at the same time fork over a chunk of their revenues. If big tech companies were somehow allowing you and me free access to content we would otherwise have to pay for, there might be a case to answer. That would be like Google Maps not only giving you directions to a restaurant but the means to also avoid paying for your meal. But using a search engine does not allow you to get free meals, nor to get around a news organisation’s pay wall. In fact, having their content pop up in search results, or shared on social media, helps Australian media companies to attract readers and sell subscriptions – something that now accounts for roughly half the revenues of some leading players such as The Australian. All you get for “free” is a snippet of a line or two from the search. For instance, when I searched for news about recently deceased US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, I got this: If you can figure out the full content of the article from that snippet, you should be using your superpowers for other, more lucrative purposes. There is a very real risk this misguided code will end up becoming law. An overzealous regulator has proposed something that stands to benefit the big media companies, who are – not surprisingly – strongly for it. Those same media companies have huge influence over public perceptions and the fate of politicians. It will be a brave elected representative who pushes back on the proposed code and draft legislation. But if politicians were serious about resolving the real issue at stake in all of this, they would act more directly. Get InDaily in your inbox. Daily. The best local news every workday at lunch time. Thanks for signing up to the InDaily newsletter. Like newspapers all around the world, Australian media and journalists are under pressure – and one thing most people agree on is that high-quality news and journalism is critical to a well-functioning democracy. Whatever the market forces that have slashed the funding of such journalism, there is a strong case for government intervention. But if the Australian government wants to subsidise high-quality journalism, it should do it itself. With the 10-year bond rate less than 1%, it would cost the government just A$18 million a year to fund the interest bill on A$2 billion of media subsidies a year. That’s 72 cents per Australian a year. And all without driving away the hugely valuable services of companies like Google and Facebook that Australian consumers love. urn:contentItem:5X98-R661-DY1R-B3G1-00000-00Payment innovations yes, but monitored and regulated2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:21ZLexisNexisPayment innovations yes, but monitored and regulated


The traditional financial system does welcome technological-financial innovations that can accelerate country-to-country payments and lower transaction costs. But their participation must be subject to clear rules and oversight, which ensure the stability of the payment system, the protection of personal data and the payment reference, the governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney, warned.


At a seminar on big tech and the future of the financial system, he said mechanisms need to be found where crypto-asset operations have their "banks of last resort", which guarantee and support transactions, in order to ensure system stability. "The financial system is the most regulated in the economy for a very simple reason: money is from the public, and history has shown us that there are many ways where financial transactions can get out of their way," he said.
He cited, for example, the prevailing fintech development in China, where "there is one of the largest asset bubbles in the world, with the operation of the so-called shadowbanks." We don't want a good idea to lead to big problems. That's why central and regulatory banks want to be aware of their operation, he said. In the same seminar, sitting to his right, was David Marcus, co-founder of Libra, the cryptoasset that Facebook wants to operate from next year. Marcus said this cryptoagent is developed to solve the big problems that the global financial system presents to users: completing direct transactions between two accounts running across different geographic networks; lower the cost of operation, and make transactions so easily, that they can be completed from a smartphone. "The current configuration of the financial system is also not great for privacy. Massive data is readily available to card operators and there is an opportunity to operate them better," he said. He warned that the Libra consortium is willing to converse with financial system supervisors and regulators to allow crypto-assets to be operated for all users in a simple way.
Libra's approach is to complete low-cost financial operations that can be performed from a smartphone between several countries, for people who are not banked. Marcus said there is no financial system that connects every financial network in the world. There are payment networks such as the European Payments Council, the Global Financial and Interbank Information Exchange Society (SWIFT), among many operating since the 1970s, he said. Direct operations between two accounts on different networks are usually difficult to operate, functioning as separate compartments from each other.
And Libra plans to facilitate this operability to send money. Right there, as an introduction, the fund's deputy managing director, David Lipton, said that the big tech stools that offer financial services are driving a change in the system. But he warned that they should be cared for, regulated and supervised like any other service offering. Your intention is to meet you.
(Source: The Economist / Internet, Information, 00:06, 17/10/2019)

"The financial system is the most regulated in the economy for a very simple reason: money is from the public, and history has shown us that there are many ways where financial transactions can get out of their way," he said.
He cited, for example, the prevailing fintech development in China, where "there is one of the largest asset bubbles in the world, with the operation of the so-called shadowbanks."
We don't want a good idea to lead to big problems. That's why central and regulatory banks want to be aware of their operation, he said.
Pound, from Facebook, defends itself
In the same seminar, sitting to his right, was David Marcus, co-founder of Libra, the cryptoasset that Facebook wants to operate from next year.
Marcus said this cryptoagent is developed to solve the big problems that the global financial system presents to users: completing direct transactions between two accounts running across different geographic networks; lower the cost of operation, and make transactions so easily, that they can be completed from a smartphone.
"The current configuration of the financial system is also not great for privacy. Massive data is readily available to card operators and there is an opportunity to operate them better," he said.
He warned that the Libra consortium is willing to converse with financial system supervisors and regulators to allow crypto-assets to be operated for all users in a simple way.
Libra's approach is to complete low-cost financial operations that can be performed from a smartphone between several countries, for people who are not banked.
International transactions
Marcus said there is no financial system that connects every financial network in the world. There are payment networks such as the European Payments Council, the Global Financial and Interbank Information Exchange Society (SWIFT), among many operating since the 1970s, he said.
Direct operations between two accounts on different networks are usually difficult to operate, functioning as separate compartments from each other. And Libra plans to facilitate this operability to send money.
Right there, as an introduction, the fund's deputy managing director, David Lipton, said that the big tech stools that offer financial services are driving a change in the system. But he warned that they should be cared for, regulated and supervised like any other service offering. Your intention is to meet you.
